thread.title: Analysis: Why Bengals beat the Bills
thread.title_full: Analysis: Why Bengals beat the Bills

title: Analysis: Why Bengals beat the Bills
text:
Activate your digital access. Analysis: Why Bengals beat the Bills Bengals writers Paul Dehner Jr. and Jim Owczarski break down the team's 34-21 victory in Buffalo. The Enquirer/Kareem Elgazzar Paul Dehner Jr. , pdehnerjr@enquirer.com 6:53 p.m. EDT October 18, 2015 Bengals cornerback Darqueze Dennard (21) is congratulated by teammate Dre Kirkpatrick after his interception in the first quarter. (Photo: The Enquirer/Kareem Elgazzar) 
THE DEHNER DECISION 
This wasn’t a poor Buffalo defense. The Bills boast a scary front seven and one of the best young cornerback tandems in football. 
The Bengals sliced and diced them in the second half to sap any drama out of Sunday afternoon at Ralph Wilson Stadium. 
Sound like a theme? Outside of the win at Baltimore and last week against Seattle the first six weeks of the season have contained little drama thanks to this offense. At this point it’s fair to wonder if any defense can slow them down as long as they stay healthy. The Bills and Rex Ryan certainly couldn’t. 
Teams can’t keep up with these weapons and heading into the bye week at 6-0 with two weeks to prepare for Pittsburgh should leave the Bengals coaches kicking back with their feet up and smile on the face. Bengals now 6-0 with win over Bills 
GAME BALL: Andy Dalton 
Giving the game ball to Andy Dalton every week might feel like a cop out, but hard to deny at any point he hasn’t been worthy. Again, Dalton orchestrated the Bengals offensive circus efficiency while the Bills threw different looks around. 
Dalton not only went without an interception, he checked masterfully into a run play against a Bear defense for the Giovani Bernard touchdown run and found the 6-inch height difference between Tyler Eifert and Bacarri Rambo for a third-quarter touchdown. 
Seven players caught passes, four others rushed. 
Dalton finished with 22 of 43 for 243 yards. He had a passer rating of 118.6. Now he has six consecutive games with a passer rating of at least 95. He’s also topped 115 in five of his first six games. The only one lower was when leading a 17-point fourth-quarter comeback against the Seahawks. Bengals middle linebacker Rey Maualuga (left) congratulates cornerback Darqueze Dennard after his interception in the first quarter against the Bills. The Bengals prevailed, 34-21.
